learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyse and apply a range of different methods and theories of history derived from multiple related approaches such as from political science, sociology, anthropology, gender studies, postcolonial studies, narrative theory, Indigenous studies, to name just a few.
Explain, understand, and analyse the important texts and ideas that have contributed to modern historical practice.
Identify, compare, and contrast the key schools of historical interpretation that together have shaped the modern discipline of History.
Demonstrate respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and perspectives particularly in relation to history and historical thinking.
Demonstrate critical thinking, creativity, and a high quality of written and oral expression.
Appreciate the historical, intellectual, social, and ethical contexts relevant to key schools in modern history writing.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to attend tutorials across the semester and participate in class discussion. Marks will be awarded for evidence of having completed the required readings for each tutorial and for engaging substantially in class discussions.

NOTE: There are no tutorials in Weeks 1, 7 and 13.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Midterm Exam that will be administered during the Week 7 Lecture, testing knowledge of the learning activities of Weeks 1-6.

AI: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Task: Your major assessment project for this course is a 2,200 word research essay. Your essay should respond to one of the topics listed below. It should be based on original research in the relevant historical literature, with at least 10 items listed in your bibliography.

Topics:

  1. Analysis of a Historian. Take an important historian from the nineteenth-, twentieth-, or twenty-first century and assess their larger significance for modern historical practice. How has their work been received by the profession and how should we regard their overall contribution to their field of study? 
  2. Analysis of a History. Take a major work of history (i.e. history book) published no earlier than the nineteenth century as your focus. How can we best characterise the author’s approach and how has it influenced or contributed to its field of study?
  3. Analysis of a School of History. Take a major school or theory of historical scholarship as your focus. Critically assess the context in which this school or theory emerged. What essential concepts characterise the work of this school or theoretical approach? What has it contributed to historical scholarship and/or practice?

Referencing style: Students must use Chicago style for references (footnotes) and bibliographies: http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/tools_citationguide/citation-guide-1.html

Word Limits: A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (2,200 words) is acceptable. Word count does not include bibliography or footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. Students must also fill out an AI disclosure sheet and submit it as the cover page for their essay.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Final exam that will consist of two parts: the first part will test knowledge of Weeks 7 to 13; the second part will be an essay question testing knowledge of the whole course. There will be plenty of choice.

AI: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week One: Course Introduction

This introductory lecture introduces the course, and explains the various activities and assessment tasks that lie ahead.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week One: Course Introduction
learning_activities.topic_description: Week One: Course Introduction This introductory lecture introduces the course, and explains the various activities and assessment tasks that lie ahead.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Two: The Birth of Professional History

This lecture addresses the role of evidence-based analysis or ‘empiricism’ in history-writing. It concentrates on the late-nineteenth century generation of historians and their search for objective truth, the collection of facts, and the aim to make history a science.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Two: The Birth of Professional History
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Two: The Birth of Professional History This lecture addresses the role of evidence-based analysis or ‘empiricism’ in history-writing. It concentrates on the late-nineteenth century generation of historians and their search for objective truth, the collection of facts, and the aim to make history a science.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Two: Empiricism and Geoffrey Elton

Tutorial reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 2

Tutorian Discussion Questions:

Geoffrey Elton, England Under the Tutors (1955), in The Houses of History, pp. 26–46.

  1. What do the title and table of contents suggest about Elton's approach to the period?
  2. What is the implied connection between national and dynastic history?
  3. What historical factors appear to be missing from Elton's account?
  4. What makes this characteristic of empiricism?
  5. How well does the work seem to live up to Elton’s empirical rhetoric?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Two: Empiricism and Geoffrey Elton
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Two: Empiricism and Geoffrey Elton Tutorial reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 2 Tutorian Discussion Questions: Geoffrey Elton, England Under the Tutors (1955), in The Houses of History, pp. 26–46. What do the title and table of contents suggest about Elton's approach to the period? What is the implied connection between national and dynastic history? What historical factors appear to be missing from Elton's account? What makes this characteristic of empiricism? How well does the work seem to live up to Elton’s empirical rhetoric?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Three: Marx and the Revolutionaries

This lecture considers the contribution of Marxist approaches to history. By concentrating on the British school of Marxist historians, we examine how figures like Eric Hobsbawm, Christopher Hill and E.P. Thompson have approached topics like revolution, social conflict and class experience. We assess the legacies of Thompson’s epic work The Making of the English Working Class.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Three: Marx and the Revolutionaries
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Three: Marx and the Revolutionaries This lecture considers the contribution of Marxist approaches to history. By concentrating on the British school of Marxist historians, we examine how figures like Eric Hobsbawm, Christopher Hill and E.P. Thompson have approached topics like revolution, social conflict and class experience. We assess the legacies of Thompson’s epic work The Making of the English Working Class.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Three: Marxism and Christopher Hill

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 3.

Tutorian Discussion Questions:

Christopher Hill, "Economic Background of the English Revolution," in The Houses of History, pp. 59–71.

  1. What are the main aspects of Hill’s argument about the economic changes of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries?
  2. In what ways can Hill’s approach be characterized as Marxist?
  3. What is the relationship between the economy on one hand and morality and customs on the other?
  4. Is Hill’s analysis of class aligned with the doctrine of ‘class in itself’ (structural) or ‘class for itself’ (consciousness)?
  5. In what way is the focus of Hill’s analysis different than Elton’s from week 2?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Three: Marxism and Christopher Hill
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Three: Marxism and Christopher Hill Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 3. Tutorian Discussion Questions: Christopher Hill, "Economic Background of the English Revolution," in The Houses of History , pp. 59–71. What are the main aspects of Hill’s argument about the economic changes of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries? In what ways can Hill’s approach be characterized as Marxist? What is the relationship between the economy on one hand and morality and customs on the other? Is Hill’s analysis of class aligned with the doctrine of ‘class in itself’ (structural) or ‘class for itself’ (consciousness)? In what way is the focus of Hill’s analysis different than Elton’s from week 2?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Four: The Quest for Total History: The Annales School

This lecture considers the ‘three waves’ of the influential French school known as the Annales historians. Their innovative use of timeframes and deep structural frameworks to human history suggest the value (but also the pitfalls) of a ‘big picture’ approach to the past. Braudel’s epic The Mediterranean pioneered a new conception of geography and social structure as a factor in human affairs, but highlighted problems when generalizing on such a grand scale. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Four: The Quest for Total History: The Annales School
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Four: The Quest for Total History: The Annales School This lecture considers the ‘three waves’ of the influential French school known as the Annales historians. Their innovative use of timeframes and deep structural frameworks to human history suggest the value (but also the pitfalls) of a ‘big picture’ approach to the past. Braudel’s epic The Mediterranean pioneered a new conception of geography and social structure as a factor in human affairs, but highlighted problems when generalizing on such a grand scale.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Four: The Annales and Fernand Braudel

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 5.

Tutorian Discussion Questions:

Fernand Braudel, The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Phillip II (1949) in The Houses of History, pp. 118–130. 

  1. What does Braudel mean when he says on page 122 that “Mountains resist the march of history”?
  2. What are some of the specific ways that the physical environment has shaped social and cultural development? 
  3. What kind of sources does Braudel rely upon and are they appropriate for the claims he seeks to make?
  4. What are the similarities and differences between Braudel’s portrayal of mountain life and Christopher Hill’s analysis of feudalism that we read in week 4?
  5. How would you characterize Braudel’s style of narration?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Four: The Annales and Fernand Braudel
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Four: The Annales and Fernand Braudel Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 5. Tutorian Discussion Questions: Fernand Braudel, The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Phillip II (1949) in The Houses of History , pp. 118–130. What does Braudel mean when he says on page 122 that “Mountains resist the march of history”? What are some of the specific ways that the physical environment has shaped social and cultural development? What kind of sources does Braudel rely upon and are they appropriate for the claims he seeks to make? What are the similarities and differences between Braudel’s portrayal of mountain life and Christopher Hill’s analysis of feudalism that we read in week 4? How would you characterize Braudel’s style of narration?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Five: Psychohistory: Freud and the Historians

This week we explore how historians have used versions of Freudian theory to explain subjective and un-stated human motives. Erikson’s work on the psychology of Adolf Hitler is used to explore the value of ‘psycho-history’. We also examine Norbert Elias’s theory of the “civilizing process” in history, referring to the change in human conduct and sentiment in a specific direction as a result of the process by which humans impose ever-increasing restraints upon themselves. And we look at the recent development of the ‘History of the Emotions’.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Five: Psychohistory: Freud and the Historians
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Five: Psychohistory: Freud and the Historians This week we explore how historians have used versions of Freudian theory to explain subjective and un-stated human motives. Erikson’s work on the psychology of Adolf Hitler is used to explore the value of ‘psycho-history’. We also examine Norbert Elias’s theory of the “civilizing process” in history, referring to the change in human conduct and sentiment in a specific direction as a result of the process by which humans impose ever-increasing restraints upon themselves. And we look at the recent development of the ‘History of the Emotions’.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Five: Psychohistory and Lyndal Roper

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 4.

Tutorian Discussion Questions:

Lyndal Roper, Oedipus and the Devil (1994) in The Houses of History, pp. 84–105.

  1. Why have historians cautioned applying psychoanalytic modes of analysis to the early modern period and why does Roper think those concerns are overblown? 
  2. How is Roper’s analysis different from previous attempts to apply a psychoanalytic method to a history of witchcraft?
  3. In what ways do Freud’s theory of the Oedipus complex inform Roper’s analysis?
  4. How does Roper use the evidence provided by the interrogation to reconstruct the multiple layers of Regina’s life story? 
  5. Do you find Roper’s psychoanalytic approach suitable in regard to the subject matter? Why or why not?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Five: Psychohistory and Lyndal Roper
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Five: Psychohistory and Lyndal Roper Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 4. Tutorian Discussion Questions: Lyndal Roper, Oedipus and the Devil (1994) in The Houses of History , pp. 84–105. Why have historians cautioned applying psychoanalytic modes of analysis to the early modern period and why does Roper think those concerns are overblown? How is Roper’s analysis different from previous attempts to apply a psychoanalytic method to a history of witchcraft? In what ways do Freud’s theory of the Oedipus complex inform Roper’s analysis? How does Roper use the evidence provided by the interrogation to reconstruct the multiple layers of Regina’s life story? Do you find Roper’s psychoanalytic approach suitable in regard to the subject matter? Why or why not?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Six: Cultural History: History Meets Anthropology

This class investigates the fruitful intersection of history with anthropology in the 1970s and 1980s. The influence of American anthropologist Clifford Geertz and his concept of ‘thick description’ provides a key focus, along with the ‘New Cultural History’ and 'Microhistory'. We will also consider the rise of the related field of 'Ethnohistory' and the attempt to study ‘culture from below.’

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Six: Cultural History: History Meets Anthropology
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Six: Cultural History: History Meets Anthropology This class investigates the fruitful intersection of history with anthropology in the 1970s and 1980s. The influence of American anthropologist Clifford Geertz and his concept of ‘thick description’ provides a key focus, along with the ‘New Cultural History’ and 'Microhistory'. We will also consider the rise of the related field of 'Ethnohistory' and the attempt to study ‘culture from below.’

learning_activities.topic:
Week Six: Cultural History and Inga Clendinnen

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 8.

Tutorian Discussion Questions:

Inga Clendinnen, “Yucatec Maya Women and the Spanish Conquest” (1982), in Houses of History, 210–232.

  1. What does Clendinnen focus upon in order to make women’s roles in this society visible?
  2. What does she suggest that this evidence reveals about women’s status?
  3. What evidence does Clendinnen rely upon in order to support her claims? Can you find examples of how she reads the documents “against the grain”?
  4. Why does she conclude that the Spanish conquest resulted in a loss of status and dignity for Yucatec Maya women?
  5. In what ways is Clendinnen’s analysis of Yucatec Maya Women influenced by the cultural anthropology of Clifford Geertz and the social history of E. P. Thompson?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Six: Cultural History and Inga Clendinnen

What does Clendinnen focus upon in order to make women’s roles in this society visible? What does she suggest that this evidence reveals about women’s status? What evidence does Clendinnen rely upon in order to support her claims? Can you find examples of how she reads the documents “against the grain”? Why does she conclude that the Spanish conquest resulted in a loss of status and dignity for Yucatec Maya women? In what ways is Clendinnen’s analysis of Yucatec Maya Women influenced by the cultural anthropology of Clifford Geertz and the social history of E. P. Thompson?

learning_activities.topic: Midsemester Break
learning_activities.topic_title: Midsemester Break
learning_activities.topic_description: Midsemester Break

learning_activities.topic:
Week Seven: Midterm Exam

The Midterm Exam will take place during the Week 7 Lecture period. There is no tutorial scheduled for this week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Seven: Midterm Exam
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Seven: Midterm Exam The Midterm Exam will take place during the Week 7 Lecture period. There is no tutorial scheduled for this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Eight: The Place of Narrative in History Writing

Story-telling is an essential feature of much history-writing, and narratives are often at the heart of historical analysis and explanation. This lecture explores the basic paradox of historical narrative: a story that cannot be invention. How is this even possible? Hayden White’s expose of the ‘meta-narratives’ of epic history-writing in the nineteenth century provides a useful antidote to inflated claims for empirical objectivity, but does that imply that history is inevitably fiction? Watchers of TV documentaries might think so. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Eight: The Place of Narrative in History Writing
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Eight: The Place of Narrative in History Writing Story-telling is an essential feature of much history-writing, and narratives are often at the heart of historical analysis and explanation. This lecture explores the basic paradox of historical narrative: a story that cannot be invention. How is this even possible? Hayden White’s expose of the ‘meta-narratives’ of epic history-writing in the nineteenth century provides a useful antidote to inflated claims for empirical objectivity, but does that imply that history is inevitably fiction? Watchers of TV documentaries might think so.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Eight: Narrative and Hayden White

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 9.

Tutorial Discussion Questions:

Hayden White, “The Fictions of Factual Representation” (1976), in Houses of History, 233–261.

  1. According to White, what are the ways in which “the discourse of the historian and that of the writer of imaginative fictions overlap, resemble, or correspond with each other”?
  2. What were the key differences between how history writing was generally regarded in the eighteenth century vs how it was regarded in the nineteenth century?
  3. Why and how did the perceived opposition between history and fiction arise?
  4. What, according to White, are the key “tropological” strategies that historians rely upon in their attempts to represent reality? (Hint: see pp. 252–256.)
  5. How does White apply his “tropological” model to Darwin’s Origin of Species, and how does this analysis relate to his general claims about historical writing?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Eight: Narrative and Hayden White
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Eight: Narrative and Hayden White Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 9. Tutorial Discussion Questions: Hayden White, “The Fictions of Factual Representation” (1976), in Houses of History , 233–261. According to White, what are the ways in which “the discourse of the historian and that of the writer of imaginative fictions overlap, resemble, or correspond with each other”? What were the key differences between how history writing was generally regarded in the eighteenth century vs how it was regarded in the nineteenth century? Why and how did the perceived opposition between history and fiction arise? What, according to White, are the key “tropological” strategies that historians rely upon in their attempts to represent reality? (Hint: see pp. 252–256.) How does White apply his “tropological” model to Darwin’s Origin of Species , and how does this analysis relate to his general claims about historical writing?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Nine: From Women's History to the History of Gender and Sexuality

Women and women’s experiences were routinely marginalized in older modes of history-writing, something that has been challenged fundamentally by women’s emancipation and feminism. Key feminist historians have taken various steps to rectify the historical imbalance, and have pioneered a range of approaches that challenge the patriarchal framework of the historical profession. In the past decade or so ‘gender’ itself has been analyzed critically as a historical phenomenon, along with masculinity and sexuality. This lecture examines this bold and radical streak of historical practice since the 1960s. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Nine: From Women's History to the History of Gender and Sexuality
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Nine: From Women's History to the History of Gender and Sexuality Women and women’s experiences were routinely marginalized in older modes of history-writing, something that has been challenged fundamentally by women’s emancipation and feminism. Key feminist historians have taken various steps to rectify the historical imbalance, and have pioneered a range of approaches that challenge the patriarchal framework of the historical profession. In the past decade or so ‘gender’ itself has been analyzed critically as a historical phenomenon, along with masculinity and sexuality. This lecture examines this bold and radical streak of historical practice since the 1960s.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Nine: Gender History and Sharon Harley

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 10.

Tutorial Discussion Questions:

Sharon Harley, “For the Good of Family and Race: Gender, Work, and Domestic Roles in the Black Community, 1880–1930” (1990), in Houses of History, 274-288.

  1. Why does Harley suggest that black women workers have largely been ignored and/or misunderstood by previous labour histories of women? (*hint* make sure you read the footnotes.)
  2. What barriers existed for black women who were seeking work during the period of Harley's study? 
  3. In what ways were the expectations of a black woman’s married life in tension with her work life? 
  4. What are some of the ways that race, gender, and class intersect in Harley’s analysis.
  5. Are there other areas of gendered experience that could be included in the analysis, particularly in light of more recent theoretical developments?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Nine: Gender History and Sharon Harley
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Nine: Gender History and Sharon Harley Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 10. Tutorial Discussion Questions: Sharon Harley, “For the Good of Family and Race: Gender, Work, and Domestic Roles in the Black Community, 1880–1930” (1990), in Houses of History , 274-288. Why does Harley suggest that black women workers have largely been ignored and/or misunderstood by previous labour histories of women? (*hint* make sure you read the footnotes.) What barriers existed for black women who were seeking work during the period of Harley's study? In what ways were the expectations of a black woman’s married life in tension with her work life? What are some of the ways that race, gender, and class intersect in Harley’s analysis. Are there other areas of gendered experience that could be included in the analysis, particularly in light of more recent theoretical developments?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Ten: Postcolonialism: Empires and Their Legacies

As overt European imperialism collapsed in the mid-20th century, a strident critique of its legacies has appeared in scholarly work by figures such as Edward Said. ‘Post-colonial’ history has been concerned with the important residues of empire in language, culture, politics and identity. This lecture outlines the emergence of this school, its importance to national and liberation movements in Africa, the Middle East, Asia and South America, and the way it encapsulates a new appreciation of power and its implications for the contemporary post-colonial globe. We also discuss the relationship between postcolonial history and Indigenous history.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Ten: Postcolonialism: Empires and Their Legacies
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Ten: Postcolonialism: Empires and Their Legacies As overt European imperialism collapsed in the mid-20th century, a strident critique of its legacies has appeared in scholarly work by figures such as Edward Said. ‘Post-colonial’ history has been concerned with the important residues of empire in language, culture, politics and identity. This lecture outlines the emergence of this school, its importance to national and liberation movements in Africa, the Middle East, Asia and South America, and the way it encapsulates a new appreciation of power and its implications for the contemporary post-colonial globe. We also discuss the relationship between postcolonial history and Indigenous history.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Ten: Postcolonial History and Henrietta Whiteman

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 12.

Tutorial Discussion Questions:

Henrietta Whiteman, “White Buffalo Woman” (1987), in Houses of History, 333–341.

  1. What is the Cheyenne cosmology and how is it different from the cosmology of mainstream empirical histories?
  2. What do we learn about the period of contact between Cheyennes and the “white skinned strangers”?
  3. What kind of evidence does the Whiteman rely upon?
  4. What does Whiteman mean when she says this constitutes an "authentic" history?
  5. In what ways does this piece represent a postcolonial approach to history?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Ten: Postcolonial History and Henrietta Whiteman
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Ten: Postcolonial History and Henrietta Whiteman Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 12. Tutorial Discussion Questions: Henrietta Whiteman, “White Buffalo Woman” (1987), in Houses of History , 333–341. What is the Cheyenne cosmology and how is it different from the cosmology of mainstream empirical histories? What do we learn about the period of contact between Cheyennes and the “white skinned strangers”? What kind of evidence does the Whiteman rely upon? What does Whiteman mean when she says this constitutes an "authentic" history? In what ways does this piece represent a postcolonial approach to history?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Eleven: Postmodernism, Poststructuralism, and the Challenge to Empiricism

Arising from fashionable trends in European (especially French) philosophy and linguistics in the 1970s and 1980s, postmodernism was an intellectual challenge to the complex of ideas that had constituted “modernism”: e.g. the belief in human progress, the ability to ascertain “truth” through the use of reason, and moral absolutes. Postmodernism thus represented an assault on the old forms of authority in historical knowledge. At the same time Foucault and others opened up new areas for historical inquiry: madness, discipline and surveillance, power, morality, and perhaps most famously, sexuality. Did the postmodernists undermine history as a credible discipline? Or were they simply a neo-idealist conspiracy, the latest in a long line of empirical skeptics? What has postmodernism actually contributed to historical understanding?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Eleven: Postmodernism, Poststructuralism, and the Challenge to Empiricism
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Eleven: Postmodernism, Poststructuralism, and the Challenge to Empiricism Arising from fashionable trends in European (especially French) philosophy and linguistics in the 1970s and 1980s, postmodernism was an intellectual challenge to the complex of ideas that had constituted “modernism”: e.g. the belief in human progress, the ability to ascertain “truth” through the use of reason, and moral absolutes. Postmodernism thus represented an assault on the old forms of authority in historical knowledge. At the same time Foucault and others opened up new areas for historical inquiry: madness, discipline and surveillance, power, morality, and perhaps most famously, sexuality. Did the postmodernists undermine history as a credible discipline? Or were they simply a neo-idealist conspiracy, the latest in a long line of empirical skeptics? What has postmodernism actually contributed to historical understanding?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Eleven: Poststructuralism and Judith Walkowitz

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 11.

Tutorial Discussion Questions:

Judith Walkowitz, “Science and the Séance: Transgressions of Gender and Genre” (1992), in Houses of History, 301–319.

  1. What does Walkowitz mean when she says that the medical men and spiritualists “engaged in a symbolic struggle, in a dialectical battle of words and images, often inverting the same metaphoric language as their opponents”?
  2. How did the Victorian séance reverse “the usual sexual hierarchy of knowledge and power”?
  3. In what ways were female mediums in danger? 
  4. What are some of the ways that Georgina Weldon manipulated discourses of gender and genre to “triumph over her enemies”? 
  5. How does this reflect a poststructural history?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Eleven: Poststructuralism and Judith Walkowitz
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Eleven: Poststructuralism and Judith Walkowitz Tutorial Reading: Green and Troup, The Houses of History , Ch. 11. Tutorial Discussion Questions: Judith Walkowitz, “Science and the Séance: Transgressions of Gender and Genre” (1992), in Houses of History , 301–319. What does Walkowitz mean when she says that the medical men and spiritualists “engaged in a symbolic struggle, in a dialectical battle of words and images, often inverting the same metaphoric language as their opponents”? How did the Victorian séance reverse “the usual sexual hierarchy of knowledge and power”? In what ways were female mediums in danger? What are some of the ways that Georgina Weldon manipulated discourses of gender and genre to “triumph over her enemies”? How does this reflect a poststructural history?

learning_activities.topic:
Week Twelve: Public History: Taking History Outside the University

Recent decades have seen a growing awareness of the application of historical inquiry and communication to areas of broad public concern. There is also a greater recognition of the value of historical insight to public issues such as heritage conservation, museum exhibitions, and the interpretation of historical sites. This lecture examines the emergence and practice of public history as a transnational development, with particular emphasis on recent Australian applications.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Twelve: Public History: Taking History Outside the University
learning_activities.topic_description: Week Twelve: Public History: Taking History Outside the University Recent decades have seen a growing awareness of the application of historical inquiry and communication to areas of broad public concern. There is also a greater recognition of the value of historical insight to public issues such as heritage conservation, museum exhibitions, and the interpretation of historical sites. This lecture examines the emergence and practice of public history as a transnational development, with particular emphasis on recent Australian applications.

learning_activities.topic:
Week Twelve: Public History and Durba Ghosh

Tutorial Reading:

Green and Troup, The Houses of History, Ch. 13.

Tutorial Discussion Questions:

Durba Ghosh, “Exhibiting Asia in Britain: Commerce, Consumption, and Globalization” (2008), in Houses of History, 355–373.

  1. What is the larger social and political context for the “Trading Spaces” exhibit?
  2. How is it, according to Ghosh, that the exhibit "simultaneously effaced and emphasised racial, cultural, and temporal differences?
  3. If the traditional story of empire is one of "colonial domination," how does the exhibit transform that narrative to make it more appealing?
  4. How did the chronological framing of the exhibit (and others discussed by Ghosh) allow for a less contentious narrative of globalisation?
  5. How does the exhibit reflect the deeper tensions and debates within the history profession and society more broadly about how best to represent Britain's colonial legacy?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Week Thirteen: Big History: Writing History in the Age of the Anthropocene

Climate change, mass extinctions, planetary crisis, and the real possibility that human life may have a finite period of existence on the earth, all force us to rethink how we understand the history of humanity. In recent years "Big History" - meaning the history of the universe from the Big Bang to the present - has become popular in schools and universities, even winning over fans such as Microsoft founder, Bill Gates. And as the human imprint on the earth grows many scientists now believe we have entered a new epoch, the "Anthropocene", in which the major cause of geological and environmental change in the world is humanity itself. If humanity's future is in doubt, how do we write its history?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week Thirteen: Big History: Writing History in the Age of the Anthropocene
